Patch Set 5:

Yay, the Jenkins CI works again!

Patch Set 5:

This is a large patch, but it is nicely isolated. I am adding an optional logging feature to the core of the PID loop calculations. This is very useful in discovering bugs and making sure the PID coefficients and bounds are working as intended.

(1 comment)
Change has been successfully merged
Is it useful to record ts here as well? Knowing ts could help debug weird integral term issues or point out that the PID loop computation is really slow.

I thought about that, but "ts" isn't a live timestamp. Instead, it's the intended sample period, which is a configuration constant that never changes. So, it would be just another column of data that never changes, which would bloat the file without adding any value.
Why are there three integral terms? are these the last three computed integral terms from the last three loops?

It is all one integral term, from the PID loop equation's point of view. However, it's computed in several different steps, in the PID loop logic. The intent is to see the intermediate values of the variables, at each of these various steps in the function, as the function's rather complicated. This is most useful for debugging.
The name "core" does not make too much sense for me... Maybe lastDump, lastData or lastContext?

I'm naming this feature "core logging" because there's already another layer of logging that can be enabled in this program, one that works at a higher level, and I needed to distinguish it. The PidCore name makes sense when it's part of the "core logging" feature. Given this, any suggestions? Calling it "dump" or "data" or "context" seems generic, and wouldn't provide any advantage.
I'm not really sure; not a native speaker... PidCoreDump? :P

Thought about that one, actually. That already has an established meaning, though. A core dump is the memory file that the kernel gives you when your program crashes. That wasn't the intention of this feature :)
I'm out of ideas then... :P Maybe just PidCoreContext, or anyone else could suggest a good name? Or it's already good enough?
I like PidCoreContext, it's descriptive.

Seems like you're worried about moved ofstreams,
https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/io/basic_ofstream/operator%3D

suggests that the move assignment operator of ofstream handles this for you.
Also looks like ofstreams are RAII,
https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/io/basic_ofstream/close

so you don't even have to close it.

Finally I don't think this explicit move assignment operator is needed
"Implicitly-defined move assignment operator

For non-union class types (class and struct), the move assignment operator performs full member-wise move assignment of the object's direct bases and immediate non-static members, in their declaration order, using built-in assignment for the scalars, memberwise move-assignment for arrays, and move assignment operator for class types (called non-virtually).
"
That's cool, didn't know that about the autogenerated move operator doing the correct thing by default. Is it worth rewriting this to make it just use the default behavior?
Thanks, I still think it's safest to write it explicitly. It's worth an experiment to see if it still works, though.

don't think an user-defined destructor is needed to close the files.
ofstreams look to be RAII and will close themselves.
Moved-from ofstreams have their file associations removed which may result in failbit being set during close (but who cares?)
Same as for previous comment.
Thanks, I still think it's safest to write it explicitly. It's worth an experiment to see if it still works, though.
output2 is not used? Worth commenting?

Part of the reason for the "core logging" feature is to debug the guts of this function, the most important function (and the most mysterious) in the entire program. I want to take a snapshot of each variable as it gets modified, even during intermediate steps. That's why the same variable is copied at many different times. Then, I can see a before-and-after of every change that happens. All of the fields in the "coreLog" structure are eventually used, as they are written to the file, for later human perusal.
Hmm, I can't trace to where output2 is modified in this CL... Am I missing anything?

The "coreLog" structure is a stashing-away place for variables at various points. None of the variables in "coreLog" are modified after they are set, by design. The entire structure is printed intact, to the log file, for later human perusal.

The variable "output" is changed below, in the if-blocks. That's why I'm taking a snapshot of it, before and after the if-blocks. The before is "output2" and the after is "output3", in the CoreLog structure.
Ah, just realized that... Sry, sth was definitely going wrong with my mind, nvm...

I thought about refactoring this function, but I don't want to change what's there already. I only want to log the values of the variables at various places within this function. I'm using the "coreLog" object as the data structure which receives all the variables for logging purposes. The already-existing "pidinfoptr" object already stores the persistent data that is remembered for successive passes through the PID loop. So, every variable in here already does get wrapped by either one or both of these data structures.
Rebased to latest master. No other changes.
Not sure if we want to keep this patch or not. It is really bloated, for what should have been a simple feature. Nonetheless, it works, and I am cleaning up an old stack of patches.
I believe you could maybe use https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/string/byte/isalnum ?
I had considered that originally, but I wanted to make sure there were explicitly no dependencies on locale.
Would that work even on small embedded C libraries that don't support locale? I am leery of introducing a locale requirement to the BMC.
but.. wouldn't this be running on a BMC that requires C++ libraries?
True. I'm still really hesitant to bring locale into a component that previously had no requirement for locale.
Found another good reason not to use locale. It will throw if, for some reason, the named locale can't be found. It's been discouraged to use throwing/exceptions in new code.

Sure, we can keep it as is.

I wasn't aware that throwing was discouraged.. wasn't that encouraged in the OpenBMC coding style? Maybe that changed?
Sorry, my bad: it's a bmcweb style standard, not an overall OpenBMC style standard.
question: could you std::move the whole struct first then just overwrite the move.moved?
I will try it. Nice, it worked!
Made sure to include logging.o in the Meson makefiles, not just the old-style makefiles, reflecting the recent change to use Meson instead
Good catch. This patch has been in review for a long time!
Does the default != operator work?

It did not work, back in 2020 when I first tried it. Our compiler is of a newer version since then. I just tried it again. Wow, it works now! Also, my earlier function prototype was not been const correct, so it probably did not match the syntax that "default" was looking for.
If it's default, can we omit them?
I just tried omitting them, and it failed to compile: no match for operator!=

Ack.

Seems like we have a more fancy one here https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/language/default_comparisons

What we have now LGTM
Interesting to know, thanks for the link.
Could you tell more about why this variable and the customized move constructor is needed?

Yes. It needs the Six Horsemen because this class contains some open file descriptors. A file descriptor can't be cleanly copied, it must be moved. And, when moving, the source object must be flagged in this way, so the destructors of both the source and the destination object can know to avoid both trying to delete the same file descriptor.
I see
I added the new Derivative fields to the logging, since that feature did not exist at the time this patch was originally written.
Need +1 again, due to code changes caused by rebase
Giving myself +2, as somebody else has already given +1
